Award.AbstractNarration:
Statistical Theory and Methodology
Persi Diaconis and Bradley Efron

The long-term goal of this project has been the development of useful tools for scientific inference, both in probability and statistics. The present proposal focuses on exponential families of probability distributions, especially as they apply to complex applications such as graphical models and high-dimensional Bayesian/frequentist computation. Specific projects include exponential families for graphs, including the effects of covariate information, and ways of using the frequentist bootstrap to compute Bayesian inferential distributions.

Exponential families include most of the well-known probability distributions -- binomial, Poisson, normal etc, -- so exponential family results have a wide scope of application. They live at the core of applied and theoretical statistics, and are of growing importance in probability theory. Graphical models, which include studies of the internet, gene expression data, and social networks such as Facebook, use exponential family structure to simplify analysis of the enormous data sets involved. Bayesian applications of the theory, increasingly popular in the "Big Data" world, are investigated here in terms of the bootstrap, a frequentist device, with the goal of connecting the two approaches.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Big Data, data science, and Artificial Intelligence have become familiar terms to the American public, though what the terms actually encompass is a good deal less familiar. All three are rooted in the literature of statistical inference. Developed over the last three centuries, most intensely during the past one hundred years, statistical inference is a mathematical-logical methodology for making sense out of information that arrives in many small noisy pieces.

Enormous increases in the flow of scientific data have raised demand for a more capacious inferential methodology. This project has been aimed at using the newest mathematical and computational tools to improve traditional statistical technology, and to develop analysis methods appropriate to Twenty-First Century scientific demands.

The revolutionary acceleration of computional speeds, by a factor of one million since the 1940s, has affected our theoretical as well as our applied techniques. Bootstrap methods for assessing the accuracy of a statistical estimator make full use of electronic computation, but have also required extensive mathematical justification to take their place in regular practice. They are just one aspect of Monte Carlo procedures that combine random search techniques with mathematical theory to solve the previously unsolvable.

In addition to basic research, this project has helped support writing of the book Computer Age Statistical Inference (B. Efron and T. Hastie). In it, the development of statistical inference and statistical algorithms is traced over the past sixty years---that is, since the introduction of modern computation. Our grant has been fully involved in this development, pursuing both mathematical and computational advances in statistics and probability theory.
